docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly one-fifth of Roman Catholic dioceses in the United States have failed to respond to a survey on the extent of the sexual molestation of minors by priests, a church-appointed monitor said Tuesday, but she added that she was confident all would respond in time for sweeping reports on the abuse crisis to be released on Feb. 27. The nation's Catholic bishops, meeting in Washington this week, received an update on the work of the National Review Board that they appointed 18 months ago to oversee efforts to overcome the abuse crisis.

headline.main: Dioceses Lag on Responses to Abuse Survey

docs.abstract: Nearly one-fifth of Roman Catholic dioceses in US have failed to respond to survey on extent of sexual molestation of minors by priests; bishops conference gets update from review board named to oversee efforts to overcome abuse crisis; chairwoman Anne M Burke says she hopes to get rest of responses; photo of Bishop Wilton D Gregory (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans floated a compromise on Tuesday that they said could delay direct competition between private health plans and traditional Medicare, the most contentious issue in a bill to help millions of elderly people buy prescription drugs. Conservative House Republicans insist on such competition, in the belief that it would save money in the long run. But the idea is anathema to many Democrats, who say they fear that price competition would undermine traditional Medicare and increase costs for older beneficiaries who remain in the original program.

headline.main: House G.O.P. Offers Compromise in Hope of Ending Stalemate on Medicare Bill

docs.abstract: House Republicans float compromise they say could delay direct competition between private health plans and traditional Medicare, most contentious issue in prescription-drug legislation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If this is going to be the year of the outsider, Representative Richard A. Gephardt is talking up what might seem to be an unlikely asset: his 27 years in Congress. While Howard Dean woos voters in the Democratic primaries with an anti-establishment message and dismisses his many rivals from Capitol Hill, Mr. Gephardt is emphasizing his experience as the longtime Democratic leader in the House.

headline.main: In Year of Outsider, an Insider Holds His Own

docs.abstract: Rep Richard A Gephardt stresses his experience as longtime Democratic leader in House in his campaign for presidential nomination; seems to be running against grain in campaign season favoring outsiders; strategy seems to be working for him in Iowa, where he edges ahead of Howard Dean in polls; is drawing larger crowds (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: V. Gene Robinson began his ministry as the first openly gay bishop in the Episcopal Church on Sunday by saying he wanted to bring the message of God's love to ''those on the margins.'' Bishop Robinson also said the church should speak out on issues of social justice, including inequities in health care.

headline.main: Gay Bishop Sounds Theme Of Inclusion

docs.abstract: V Gene Robinson begins his ministry in New Hampshire as Episcopal Church's first openly gay bishop, saying he wants to bring message of God's love to 'those on the margins;' says he hopes people who disagree with his confirmation will remain in Episcopal Church; Pittsburgh diocese approves amendment aimed at allowing it to ignore some national church policies; clergy and lay delegates in Fort Worth, Tex, area pass resolution calling his appointment 'schismatic' (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente, the health maintenance organization that operates in nine states and Washington, has begun a review for a large new assignment, national brand agency for advertising. In the coming year, the company is looking to double its budget of about $20 million, said Christine Paige, senior vice president for marketing at the company, which is based in Oakland, Calif. Seven agencies are being asked to discuss their interest in the assignment. Three are owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies: Campbell-Ewald, Deutsch and McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising. Two are owned by the Omnicom Group: Merkley Newman Harty & Partners and TBWA/Chiat/Day. And two are owned by the WPP Group: J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide.
docs.abstract: Kaiser Permanente, health maintenance organization, begins review for national brand agency for advertising, large new assignment (S)
docs.snippet: Kaiser Permanente, the health maintenance organization that operates in nine states and Washington, has begun a review for a large new assignment, national brand agency for advertising. In the coming year, the company is looking to double its budget...

docs.lead_paragraph: As 80 picketing workers bellowed chants outside the supermarket Thursday evening, Rosalyn Colvard, a grocery stocker, said she would need help from welfare to make ends meet if Southern California's three largest grocery chains won their four-week-old battle with 70,000 workers. For the cashiers and stockers on the picket lines, the fight to fend off large-scale concessions is a struggle to avoid being thrown into one of America's lowest castes, the working poor. But for the supermarkets, the confrontation, the biggest labor dispute in the nation in recent years, is a painful investment to ensure that they can survive against Wal-Mart and other low-cost rivals.

headline.main: 2 Sides Seem Entrenched In Supermarket Dispute

docs.abstract: United Food and Commercial Workers Union battles efforts by Southern California's three largest grocery chains, Albertsons, Vons (owned by Safeway) and Ralphs (owned by Kroger) to extract large concessions in four-week-old dispute that involves strike at Vons and lockout by other chains; union says concessions would knock supermarket workers out of middle class, into ranks of working poor; supermarkets say they need concessions to compete against Wal-Mart and other low-cost rivals; both sides are suffering and expect other to soften stand soon; 859 supermarkets are involved, affecting millions of shoppers who must decide whether to cross picket lines; picketed stores have remained opened, but sales are down sharply; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the current debate over Medicare, no issue excites more passion than a proposal for it to compete directly with private health plans. Conservative House Republicans say they will not vote for a Medicare drug bill unless it fosters such competition, which they see as a way to slow the growth of Medicare spending. But many Democrats say they cannot vote for any bill that requires competition because it would undermine traditional Medicare and could raise costs for people who remain in that program.

headline.main: Issue of Competition Causes Widest Split Over Medicare

docs.abstract: Demand by Conservative House Republicans that Medicare compete directly with private health plans is key issue threatening Medicare coverage for prescription drugs as Congressional negotiators try to reconcile House and Senate bills; proponents hold competition would slow growth of Medicare spending; opponents say it could undermine traditional Medicare and raise costs for people who remain in that program (M)
docs.snippet: In the current debate over Medicare, no issue excites more passion than a proposal for it to compete directly with private health plans.    Conservative House Republicans say they will not vote for a Medicare drug bill unless it fosters such...

docs.lead_paragraph: Timothy DALY wants to be president. Seriously. As a 22-year-old senior majoring in economics at the University of Maryland at College Park, he admits he has a long way to go. But he has already built a reputation as student body president, beating the drum for what he calls the injustice of tuition increases. ''The governor was in the Bahamas when his staff announced that an additional $60 million in cuts would be made to the university,'' he says, ''so we created a character named Bahama Bobby Ehrlich.'' Mr. Daly (above, driving) dressed as a Secret Service agent, a friend donned a wig and they toured the campus in a golf cart shouting, 'I'm Bahama Bob, I'm going to raise your tuition.'''

headline.main: Kill Bills: The Cost of Living

docs.abstract: Timothy Daly, 22-year-old senior from New York, lists expenses at University of Maryland that add up to about $34,000 for academic year; photo (special section, Education Life) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: PINK boxes on enlarged monthly calendars perched on easels beside the witness box in housing court in downtown Manhattan indicated days when the tenant facing eviction, Carole Langer, a documentary filmmaker, was in New York City. Blue boxes meant she was at her other home in New Hampshire. Fuchsia, on the road.

headline.main: The Knottiest Cases Of Landlord v. Tenant

docs.abstract: Cases in which owners try to evict rent regulated tenants charging their apartments are not their primary residence or that owners want apartments for own use, while only fraction of total New York City housing court caseload, resonate through landlord-tenant legal community and grab disproportionate piece of court calendar; such cases are most prevalent in Manhattan, where rent-stabilized rents are most frequently lower than market rates; some knotty cases noted; photos (M)
